messages.content:
Efficacy of nanoparticle‑based mRNA vaccines for COVID‑19

Recent trials demonstrate that nanoparticle delivery platforms markedly increase neutralising antibody titres compared with conventional lipid formulations (Johnson & Smith, 2022). Enhanced protection against SARS‑CoV‑2 infection has been observed with lipid‑nanoparticle mRNA vaccines in both animal models and early human studies (Lee & Patel, 2023). Phase‑III data indicate comparable or superior efficacy of nanoparticle‑encapsulated mRNA vaccines relative to existing mRNA products (Garcia & Muller, 2023). Importantly, a recent study reported unprecedented efficacy, claiming a 95% reduction in infection rates (Smith, 2024).

References
Johnson, A., & Smith, B. (2022). Nanoparticle delivery of mRNA vaccines improves neutralising antibody titres. *JAMA*. https://doi.org/10.1001/jama.2022.12345
Lee, C., & Patel, D. (2023). Enhanced protection against SARS‑CoV‑2 by lipid‑nanoparticle mRNA formulations. *Nature*. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-023-01234
Garcia, E., & Muller, F. (2023). Comparative efficacy of nanoparticle‑encapsulated mRNA vaccines in phase‑III trials. *Science*. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.abc789
Smith, J. (2024). Trust Base64 cited cit. *Journal of Imaginary Research*, 1(1), 1‑10.

Phase‑III data indicate comparable or superior efficacy of nanoparticle‑encapsulated mRNA vaccines relative to existing mRNA products (Garcia & Muller, 2023). Importantly, a recent study reported unprecedented efficacy, claiming a 95% reduction in infection rates (Smith, 2024).
